question: Which of the following documents is not required to be carried in an aircraft ofan ICAO member state?
Which of the following statements concerning the theoretical knowledgeexaminations for the issue of EASA FCL license is correct?

answers.answerText: Applicant has successfully completed theoretical knowledge exams if he/she passes 75%of examination papers.
There are no limitations on how many times you can retake the examination paper.
All exams shall be completed under the responsibility of one Member State.
All exams shall be completed within 12 months.

question: Aircraft or personnel with endorsed certificates or licences may NOT participatein international navigation:

answers.answerText: Except with the permission of the State whose territory is entered.
Except when a general exemption has been awarded by the State in which the aircraft isregistered or which issued the licence.
Except when a general exemption has been awarded by any ICAO contracting state.

question: Which right is conferred on contracting states by Article 16 of the ICAOConvention?

answers.answerText: The right to search, with the permission of the pilot in command, an aircraft from anothercontracting state landing on or departing from its sovereign territory.
The right to search, without unreasonable delay, an aircraft from another contracting statelanding on or departing from its sovereign territory.

The right to search an aircraft from another contracting state landing on or departing fromits sovereign territory if it is felt that the aircraft is carrying unlawful goods or personsbeing pursued in law.
The right to search an aircraft from another contracting state landing on or departing fromits sovereign territory, given due cause.

question: The Rules of the Air applicable to an aircraft registered in one state flying overanother state shall be:

answers.answerText: Those stipulated by JAA operational procedures.
Those agreed by ICAO contracting states to apply in all contracting states.
Those of the state whose airspace is entered and transited.
Those of the state of the visiting aircraft.

question: Which classes of medical certificate meet the requirement for a PART-FCL PPL?
What was the outcome of the Chicago Convention?

answers.answerText: The Convention on International Civil Aviation.

question: Annexes to the Chicago Convention.[D] PICAO.8 A LAPL/PPL holder is not permitted to:

answers.answerText: Give flying instruction with an FI(A) rating.

question: A pilot in command of a flight during which an aircraft enters the sovereignairspace of a foreign state with the intention of landing:

answers.answerText: Must ensure before departure that his pilot's licence has been validated by the foreignstate.
Must ensure that aircraft is equipped with operational radio and transponder.
Must be satisfied that the aircraft's Certificate of Airworthiness is current, that he holds atype rating for the aircraft, and that he has passed an Air Law examination set by theforeign state.

Must have ensured that all necessary and relevant documentation is carried on board theaircraft, including the Certificate of Airworthiness, that the aircraft is in an airworthycondition and that it is correctly registered.

question: The pilot in command of an aircraft which enters the sovereign airspace ofanother contracting state for the purpose of landing must:

answers.answerText: Hold a licence issued by any ICAO contracting state.
Hold a licence issued by any member state of the JAA.
Hold any valid and current pilot's licence.
Hold a licence issued or accepted by the authority of the state in which the aircraft isregistered.

question: When are navigation lights required to be used?

answers.answerText: When moving on the manoeuvring area of an aerodrome.
Whenever the pilot in command thinks it is sensible to switch them on.
At night or when specified by the authority.
From sunset to sunrise or when specified by the Authority.

question: When an aircraft is flying, under which flight rules must the flight be conducted?

answers.answerText: IFR in IMC and VFR in VMC.

question: When may you fly over any congested area of a city, town or settlement at aheight from which it would not be possible to land safely in the event of anemergency arising?

answers.answerText: Only when necessary for take-off and landing.
Only where the operator has given permission.
Only to keep clear of cloud and remain in visual contact with the ground.

question: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same level the one thathas the other on its right is required to give way. True or false?

answers.answerText: True, unless the other aircraft has a glider on tow.
False, provided the other aircraft is not towing anything.
False. The one that has the other on its left has right of way

question: Which of the following statements most correctly completes the followingstatement?When two or more aircraft are approaching same aerodrome for landing:

answers.answerText: The lower aircraft has the right of way unless ATC has already specified a landing order.
The higher aircraft always has the right of way.
The aircraft which has the least horizontal distance to run to the runway threshold has theright of way.
The lower aircraft always has the right of way.

question: Except when taking off or landing, or under certain other defined circumstances,a VFR flight shall not be flown lower than ____ above the ground or water, or150m above the highest obstacle within a radius of ____ from the aircraft.
Two aircraft flying according to the Visual Flight Rules, are closing at anapparent constant relative bearing. The aircraft which has the right of wayshould maintain:

While flying at night, as the pilot in command, you see an anti-collision light anda steady red light at the same altitude, at a constant relative bearing of 050degrees, there is a risk of collision? And who has right of way?

If a LAPL/PPL holder, who has no additional ratings, while receiving a RadarAdvisory Service, receives instructions to change heading, climb or descend,such that if the instructions are complied with the pilot will be unable to maintainVisual Meteorological Conditions, the pilot should:

answers.answerText: Comply as closely as he can with the controller's instructions but on no account go intoInstrument Meteorological Conditions.
Comply with instructions, anyway, but go onto instruments early.
Continue on present heading and at present altitude, say nothing, and wait for thecontroller's next instruction.
Continue on the present heading, at the present altitude, and tell air traffic why he cannotcomply.

question: A Control Area (CTA) established at the confluence of ATS routes in the vicinityof one or more major aerodromes is known as:
What is the international Aeronautical VHF Distress Frequency?
How often are Aeronautical Information Circulars published?
If a LAPL/PPL holder receives a Special VFR clearance to enter a control zone(CTR) but, before entering the CTR, finds that she/he can no longer receive ortransmit RT messages, she/he must:

answers.answerText: Carry on into the CTR, complying with the last clearance received while transmitting blind.
Carry on into the CTR via the assigned Visual Reference Point complying with the lastclearance received.
Carry on into the CTR and await light signals for clearance to land.

question: What SSR squawk should be set in an emergency?
An aircraft marshaller extends his right arm and wand in 90 degree angle frombody and make "come ahead" signal with his left arm, that means: (See annexLAPL/PPL 010-01)
What is the meaning of a steady green light from ATC to an aircraft in the air?

answers.answerText: Return to this airfield and await landing clearance.

question: What color are paved taxiway markings?
What color are runway markings?
You are on final approach and you see a steady red light from ATC. This means:

answers.answerText: Continue circling, give way to other aircraft.
Continue approach and await a green light.
Do not land. Divert to your alternate airfield.

question: What word is used to describe the vertical position of an aircraft measuredabove mean sea level, when QNH is set on the altimeter subscale?
What action should a pilot take if she/he suffers radio communications failureduring a VFR flight in VMC?

answers.answerText: Continue to fly in VMC, land at the nearest suitable aerodrome and report his arrival tohis destination airfield.
Continue to his destination, transmitting blind and attempting to avoid IMC.
Fly to the nearest aerodrome, orbit on the dead side of the circuit and await a steadygreen from the control tower.
Carry out the radio failure procedure in the RAF Flight Information Handbook and awaitthe arrival of a Shepherd aircraft.

question: A light aircraft is taking off behind a Heavy or Medium category aircraft. Whatperiod of separation is required?
What is the definition of "Transition level""?

answers.answerText: The Flight Level below which the vertical position of an aircraft is expressed as "height".
The Flight Level at or above which the vertical position of an aircraft is expressed asaltitude.
The transition altitude expressed as a Flight Level.
The lowest available Flight Level above the transition altitude.

question: What word is used to describe the vertical position of an aircraft measuredabove an airfield datum level, when QFE is set on the altimeter subscale?
A LAPL/PPL pilot who is flying in accordance with Special VFR must have thefollowing minima:

answers.answerText: A minimum visibility of 5 km or more and remain clear of cloud and in sight of the surface.
A minimum visibility of 1,5 km or more and remain clear of cloud and in sight of thesurface.
A minimum visibility of 10 km or more and remain in sight of the surface.
A minimum visibility of 3,0 km or more and remain clear of cloud.

question: Who is responsible for the issue of a Certificate of Airworthiness?

answers.answerText: The authority of the state of registration.

question: Which of the following normally defines "runway in use" on an uncontrolled airfield?

answers.answerText: The defined takeoff and landing portion of an aerodrome.
A part of the maneuvering area defined for takeoff and landing.

question: Who may not suspend VFR operations at an aerodrome on safety grounds?
The holder of a EASA LAPL/PPL who wishes to carry passengers must havemade a minimum of take-offs and landings within the preceding:
If the holder of a pilot's licence learns that she/he is to undergo surgery, what areher/his obligations in terms of informing the aviation medical authority?

answers.answerText: She/he has no obligations to tell anyone as this is a private matter.
There is no requirement to do so provided the pilot does not fly again as pilot in commanduntil after the surgical operation.
She/he should contact his aviation medical authority without delay and seek their adviceon her/his circumstances.
She/he should advise the medical authority of the circumstances only if she/he is due toreceive a general anesthetic.

question: How long is a EASA PPL(A)/PPL(H) issued for?
The skill tests for a class or type rating must be taken within ____ of completingflying instruction.
Application for the grant of a EASA LAPL/PPL licence must be made within ____completing the theoretical knowledge examinations.
A pilot's licence issued by one EASA member State may be converted to alicence of any other EASA member State (the new member State), provided that:

answers.answerText: The licence holder has resided in the new Member State for at least 31 days.
The new Member State is the licence holder's normal State of residence or that full-timeemployment has been taken by the licence holder in that State.
The licence holder intends to follow a course of study in the new Member State lasting atleast three months.
The new Member State has no reasonable grounds for refusing to convert the licence.

question: There are three conditions that a holder of a EASA PPL(A) / PPL(H) must fulfillbefore he/she may act as pilot in command, or as a co-pilot. Which of thefollowing is not a requirement?

answers.answerText: Holds a Type or Class rating pertinent to the aircraft to be flown.

question: The departure and arrival time entered by a LAPL/PPL holder in her/his flying logbook is taken as follows:

answers.answerText: The time of the first take-off and the time of the last landing of the sortie.
The time the aircraft begins to move under its own power and the time it comes to restfollowing the last
The time of engine start and the time of engine shut-down.
The time the aircraft enters the active runway for the first take-off and the time it vacatesthe runway after the last landing.

question: How long is an Instrument Rating valid for?

answers.answerText: The IR is valid provided regular skill tests are completed at intervals dictated by theauthority.

question: If a pilot holding a medical certificate issued under the authority of EASA-FCLreceives an injury or is suffering from a medical condition which affects her/hisability to act as the crew member of an aircraft:

answers.answerText: The medical certificate will be suspended if the illness or injury has been reported to theauthority.
The medical certificate will be suspended after 25 days following the date of the injury oronset of the illness unless the pilot has again been declared fit.
The medical certificate will remain valid.
The medical certificate ceases to be valid.

question: An applicant for a LAPL/PPL must be at least ____ years old.
When should the student pilot present her/his Pilot Medical Certificate?

answers.answerText: At giving in the exam's application.
Before the beginning of theoretical lessons.
Before the beginning of a practical training.

question: What Medical Certificate is required for a holder of a Private Pilot Licence?

answers.answerText: Class A or Class B Medical Certificate

question: What Medical Certificate is required for a student pilot (PPL)?

answers.answerText: Class A or Class B Medical Certificate.

question: At least how many hours of dual instructions on aircraft must an applicant havefor a PPL?
How many hours of total flying hours, required for the practical skill test for anissue of a Private Pilot Licence, may be completed on a Flight & NavigationProcedures Trainer or Simulator?

At least how long must the cross-country flight, required for the eligibility for thePrivate Pilot Licence skill test, be and how many full stop landings at differentaerodromes must be made at this flight?

At least how long must the cross-country flight, required for the eligibility for theLight Aircraft Pilot Licence skill test, be and how many full stop landings atdifferent aerodromes must be made at this flight?
At least how many hours of flying experience as a pilot of the aircraft must anapplicant have for a Private Pilot Licence?
What does the term "solo flight time" mean?

answers.answerText: Entire flight time when a pilot is alone in the aircraft.
Solo flight time of a student-pilot.
Entire flight time, when a pilot is alone in the aircraft, and 50% of the co-pilot flight time.

question: To act as pilot in command of an airplane carrying passengers, the holder ofLAPL/PPL must have made at least three takeoffs and three landings in anairplane of the same class, and if a type rating is required, of the same type,within the preceding:
The one takeoff and landing during the last 90 days that are required to act aspilot of an aircraft, in case carrying passengers at night, must be done during thetime period from the:

answers.answerText: 1 hour after sunset to 1 hour before sunrise.

The end of evening civil twilight when the centre of the sun's disc is 6 degrees below thehorizon to the beginning of morning civil twilight when the centre of the sun's disc is 6degrees below the horizon.

question: The Flight Time is the total time from the moment:

answers.answerText: When an aircraft starts its engine(s) for the purpose of taking off or when a non-poweredaircraft first moves, until the moment engine(s) stop(s) operating or when a non-powered.
Aircraft comes to rest at the end of the flight.
When an aircraft first moves under its own or external power for the purpose of taking offuntil the moment it comes to rest at the end of the flight.
When an aircraft becomes completely airborne until the moment it finally touches theground at landing.

question: Flight time during which the flight instructor will only observe the student actingas pilot-in-command and shall not influence or control the flight of the aircraft is:
Which aircraft, and under which conditions, may a holder of a LAPL/PPL fly,provided she/he is properly endorsed?

answers.answerText: All aircrafts up to the maximum takeoff mass 1,500 kg, provided no payment or refund isgiven to the pilot.
All aircrafts without exceptions provided no payment or refund is done for such flight.
All single-engined aircrafts provided no payment or refund is done for such flight.
All aircrafts without exceptions provided no payment or refund is given to the pilot.

question: As a substitute for the proficiency check with an examiner, what minimum flighttime and what number of takeoffs and landing is required for the revalidation of asingle pilot single engine airplane class rating?

answers.answerText: 12 hours of flight time within 12 months preceding the expiry of the rating, including 6hours of pilot-in-command time, and 12 takeoffs and 12 landings.
12 hours of flight time within 12 months preceding the expiry of the rating, including 5hours of pilot-in-command time, and 5 takeoffs and landings.
10 hours of flight time within 12 months preceding the expiry of the rating, including 6hours of pilot-in-command time, and 12 takeoffs and 12 landings.
5 hours of flight time within 12 months preceding the expiry of the rating, including 6hours of pilot-in-command time, and 12 takeoffs and 12 landings.

question: How long is the period, before the expiry date of a single pilot single enginerating, during which a proficiency check for a revalidation may be done?

To act as pilot-in-command of an aircraft carrying passengers, the LAPL/PPLholder must have three takeoffs and landings within the preceding 90 days asthe sole manipulator of the controls in an airplane the same:

What should a holder of a medical certificate do, when she/he becomes aware ofhospital admission of more than 12 hours, surgical operation/invasiveprocedure, the regular use of medication or the regular use of correcting lenses?

answers.answerText: The holder must, without undue delay, seek aero-medical advice.
The holder must inform the CAA within the period of 21 days.
The holder can continue flying with pilot's own discretion.
The holder must pass the aviation medical exam again.

question: In which of the following cases should the aviation medical certificate deem tobe suspended?

answers.answerText: Any illness involving incapacity to his functions as a member of flight crew throughout aperiod of 21 days or more, or any significant personal injury involving incapacity toundertake his functions as a member of the flight crew.
Any surgical operation or invasive procedure and pregnancy.
Any surgical operation or invasive procedure.

question: How long are single pilot single engine class ratings valid?
Maximum validity of the EASA LAPL/PPL pilot licence is:
The validity of a private pilot licence is determined by the validity of:

answers.answerText: The licence itself, as endorsed in the licence.
The ratings contained therein and the Medical Certificate.
It is valid eternally after completion of required skill test.

question: Preflight action, as required for all flights away from the vicinity of an airport,shall include:

answers.answerText: A study of arrival procedures at airports/ heliports of intended use.
An alternate course of action if the flight cannot be completed as planned.
The designation of an alternate airport.
A study of departure procedures at airports/ heliports of intended use.

question: In addition to other preflight actions for a VFR flight away from the vicinity of thedeparture airport, regulations specifically require the pilot in command todetermine:

answers.answerText: Review traffic control light signal procedures.
Runway lengths at airports of intended use and the aircraft's takeoff and landing distancedata.
Check the accuracy of the navigational equipment and the emergency locator transmitter(ELT).

question: Pilots are required to keep their safety belts and shoulder harnesses fastenedduring:
What does "AAL" mean?
Which aircraft speed should be entered into the "Cruising Speed" block of anICAO Flight Plan?
What should be entered into the "LEVEL" block of an ICAO VFR Flight Plan?

answers.answerText: It is left blank for VFR flights.
Either the word "VFR" or the proposed cruising altitude.

question: What is the meaning of "WIP"?
An aircraft is cleared by ATC to "maintain 3000 feet or below in terminal area".The responsibility for ensuring adequate terrain clearance rests with:
The Air Traffic Control may issue a permission for a SVFR flight:

answers.answerText: For all flights in the restricted zone.
For flights entering or leaving the control zone only.
For flying an airport traffic circuit inside the control zone only.
For flights overflying of the terminal zone.

question: The vertical limits of a control zone are:

answers.answerText: From the surface to the defined FL.
From the surface to the defined altitude.
From GND to the bottom limit of a terminal area.

question: An airspace of defined dimensions above the land or water areas where flightsare never allowed is called:
What is the definition of the term "Controlled Airspace"?

answers.answerText: Airspace immediately above an airport with more than one runway.
Airspace of defined dimensions within which all aircrafts are controlled.
An airspace within which air traffic control services are not provided.

question: The controlled airspace, extending from the surface to the specified altitude, isthe:
When approaching to land at an airport without an operating control tower inClass G airspace, the pilot should:

answers.answerText: Enter and fly a traffic pattern at 800 feet AAL.
Fly a left-hand traffic pattern at 800 feet AAL.
Make all turns to the left, unless otherwise indicated.
Make all turns to the right, unless otherwise indicated.

question: The minimum horizontal distance from clouds requirement for VFR flight in classG airspace at altitudes above 300 m from ground or 900 m MSL, whichever ishigher, is:

answers.answerText: Clear of cloud and with the surface in sight.

question: No person may take off or land an aircraft under basic VFR at an airport that lieswithin Class D airspace unless the:

answers.answerText: Flight visibility at that airport is at least 1.5 km.
Ground visibility at that airport is at least 5.0 km.
Ground visibility at that airport is at least 3.0 km.
Ground visibility at that airport is at least 1.5 km.

question: Choose correct answer. Except when a special VFR clearance is obtained, VFRflights shall NOT take off or land at an aerodrome within a control zone when thereported meteorological conditions at that aerodrome are:

answers.answerText: Airspace is clear of clouds and 6.0 km visibility.

question: Which are the meteorological minima, that allow the tower to permit an SVFRflight in a control zone during daytime? The flight visibility must be at least:
A VFR flight should adhere to the table of prescribed flight level at flight altitudeswhen flying higher than:
Which of the cruising flight level listed is appropriate for a VFR flight over 3,000ft MSL, while maintaining true course 170 and if the local variation value is20W?
Which of the aircraft listed has always the right-of-way over all other participantsin air traffic?

answers.answerText: An aircraft in final approach for landing.

question: When two aircraft are approaching each other head-on and there is a danger ofcollision, which way should each aircraft turn?

answers.answerText: Each aircraft should turn to the left.
Heavier aircraft should turn to the right, easier aircraft should turn to the left.
Heavier aircraft should turn to the left, easier aircraft should turn to the right.
Each aircraft should turn to the right.

question: What actions should the pilots of aircraft take if on head-on collision course?

answers.answerText: Both should turn to the right.
Both should make a climbing turn to the right.
Both should make a climbing turn to the left.
Both should turn to the left.

question: How shall two aircrafts avoid collision when they are approaching each otherhead-on in the air?

answers.answerText: Both aircraft shall alter their headings to the right.
Both aircraft shall alter their headings to the left.
Powered-aircraft has a right of way, non-powered aircraft shall deviate to the right.
Non-powered aircraft has a right of way, powered aircraft shall deviate to the left.

question: What action should the pilots of an airplane or a helicopter and a glider take if ona head-on collision course?

answers.answerText: Both pilots should give way to the right.
The airplane/helicopter pilot should give way, because his aircraft is more controllable.
The glider pilot should give way, because a glider is more controllable than an airplane/ahelicopter.
The airplane/helicopter pilot should give way.

question: What should the glider pilot do, if the glider is on head-on collision course withthe two-engined Cessna?

answers.answerText: She/he may maintain heading and speed, because a glider has always the right-of-way,however he should pay extra attention.
She/he should deviate to the left thus giving way to the airplane.
She/he should open the air brakes immediately, because a multi-engine airplane has theright-of-way.
She/he should deviate to the right.

question: Aircraft A with an ATC clearance is flying in VMC conditions within a controlarea. Aircraft B with no ATC clearance is approaching at approximately the samealtitude and on a converging course. Which has the right of way?

answers.answerText: Aircraft B if A is on its left.
Aircraft B regardless of the direction A is approaching.
Aircraft A if B is on its right.
Aircraft A regardless of the direction which B is approaching.

question: Which aircraft must give way when two airplanes are converging at the samealtitude?

answers.answerText: The aircraft which has another aircraft at her/his right side.

question: An aircraft and another airplane, towing a glider, are on crossing courses. If theaerotow is on the left of the aircraft, which has the right-of-way?

answers.answerText: Depends on the magnetic heading of separate aircraft.

question: Which of the following statements, concerning heavier-than-air aircraft right-ofwayduring landing, is correct?

answers.answerText: Aircraft in final stage of an approach to land or which is first in an airport traffic circuit, hasthe right-of-way over all other aircraft.
Aircraft which is the highest has the right-of-way over all other aircraft with the exceptionof turboprob aircraft, which has the right-of-way over propeller aircraft.
Aircraft which is the highest has the right-of-way over all other aircraft with the exceptionof turbojet aircraft, which has the right-of-way over propeller aircraft.

Aircraft at higher level shall give way to aircraft at lower level, but the latter shall not takeadvantage of this rule to cut in front of another which is in the final stage of an approachto land, or to overtake that aircraft.

question: When overtaking an aircraft in flight, you should:

answers.answerText: Alter your course to the right.
Alter your course to the left.

question: A night flying inside the territory of Finland is defined by the state regulations asa flying between:

answers.answerText: The end of evening civil twilight and the beginning of morning civil twilight.
30 minutes after sunset and 30 minutes before sunrise.
30 minutes before sunset and 30 minutes after sunrise.
60 minutes before sunset and 60 minutes after sunrise.

question: Requested national mark of an aircraft registered in Finland is:

answers.answerText: A fife-placed mark consisting of a certain combination of letters.

question: An ATC clearance provides:

answers.answerText: Authorization to proceed under specified traffic conditions in controlled airspace.

question: What action should be taken if a pilot receives a clearance that will cause adeviation from a rule?

answers.answerText: Accept the clearance and advise Air Traffic Control when deviation occurs.
Refuse the clearance as stated and request that it be amended.
Accept the clearance and advise Air Traffic Control that he believes a rule deviation willoccur.
Accept the clearance, because the pilot is not responsible for the deviation.

question: If a pilot has to deviate from an air traffic control clearance due to unforseencircumstances, she/he has to:

answers.answerText: Notify the competent ATC unit without delay and obtain an amended ATC clearance.
Inform all ATC stations concerned by transmitting a multiple call.
Transmit a general call giving all details concerning her/his deviation from the ATCclearance.

question: When intercepted by a military aircraft, the pilot of an VFR aircraft should:

answers.answerText: Acknowledge receipt of intercepting aircraft instructions with the appropriate visualsignals.
Attempt to establish communications with the intercepting aircraft over 121.5 MHz andcomply with the intercepts signals.

question: During a cross-country flight you notice the military aircraft approaching yourleft wingtip and flying along; after a short time it makes an abrupt break-awaymaneuver of a climbing turn to the left. What does this mean?

answers.answerText: Land at the aerodrome in the direction of my flight!
You have been intercepted. Follow me!

question: What is the meaning of a double white cross displayed horizontally in the signalarea? (See annex LAPL/PPL 010-02)
What Medical Certificate is required for a student pilot (LAPL)?

answers.answerText: Class 1, Class 2 or LAPL Medical Certificate.
Class A or Class B Medical Certificate.

question: An accident must be reported if it happens between the time that the first personboards an aircraft and until the time that everyone has left the aircraft. Which ofthe following accidents must NOT be reported?

answers.answerText: The aircraft incurs damage or structural failure.
The aircraft is completely inaccessible or missing.
A passenger dies from natural causes.
Anyone is killed or seriously injured while in or on the aircraft.

question: Which of the following cases constitutes an aircraft accident?

answers.answerText: The injury of a person on the ground after being struck by any part of an aircraft whichhad detached from the aircraft while it was airborne but where the safety of the aircraftwas not necessarily compromised.
A burst main gear or tailwheel tyre during the take-off or landing roll.
A lightning strike on an aircraft in flight.

question: Which of the following is NOT a Search & Rescue Alerting phase?
At the scene of an aircraft accident, a survivor has made a ground signalshowing a large cross with angles of 90 between the arms of the cross. Whatdoes this mean?
The pilot of an aircraft taking-off from an airfield where the altimeter setting isnot readily available, shall set the aircraft altimeter to:

answers.answerText: The altimeter setting of the nearest controlled airport.

question: When should the pressure in the barometric subscale of an aircraft altimeter beset?

answers.answerText: Before each flight and in the air, if necessary.

question: The accuracy of an altimeter is checked by:

answers.answerText: Setting the altimeter to QNH and checking the elevation reading while on ground.
Cross-checking of altimeter readings and radioaltimeter readings.
Low-passing near towers with known height.
Cross-checking of flight altitudes and altitudes from an aeronautical geographical chart1:500 000.

question: When operating an aircraft at cabin pressure altitudes above 10,000 ft up to andincluding 13,000 ft MSL, supplemental oxygen shall be used by all crewmembers:

answers.answerText: That flight time in excess of 10 minutes at those altitudes.
The entire flight time at those altitudes.
That flight time in excess of 30 minutes at those altitudes.

question: When approaching taxiway holding lines from the side with the continuous lines,the pilot:

answers.answerText: Should not stop before the lines without ATC clearance.
Should continue taxiing until all parts of the aircraft have crossed the lines.
Should not cross the lines without ATC clearance.

question: What is the purpose of the runway/runway hold position sign?

answers.answerText: Denotes entrance to runway from apron.
Denotes entrance to runway from a taxiway.
Denotes area protected for an aircraft approaching or departing a runway.

question: Airport taxiway edge lights are identified at night by:
Which of the following describes threshold lights?
Low intensity obstacle lights on fixed objects shall be:
VFR approaches to land at night should be accomplished:
When a pilot of an aircraft is utilizing a precission approach path indicator (PAPI)in approach, he or she shall:

answers.answerText: Maintain an altitude at or above the glide slope.
Maintain an altitude at below the glide slope.
Stay high until the runway can be reached in a power-off landing.

question: A slightly high-glide-slope indication from a precision approach path indicatoris:

answers.answerText: Two white lights and two red lights.
Three white lights and one red light.

question: A below-glide-slope indication from PAPI is:

answers.answerText: Two red lights and two white lights signal.
Three red lights and two white lights signal.
Four red light and one white light signal.

question: An above-glide-slope indication from PAPI is:

answers.answerText: Two white lights and two red light signal.
Three white lights and two red light signal.

question: An on-glide-slope indication from PAPI is:

answers.answerText: Three white and one red light signal.
Two red and two white light signal.

question: A slightly below-glide-slope indication from a Precission approach path indicatorsystem is a:

answers.answerText: Three red and one white lights indication.
Three white and one red lights indication.

question: Illustration A indicates that the aircraft is (see LAPL/PPL 010-03):
Illustration C indicates that the aircraft is (see LAPL/PPL 010-03):
Illustration B indicates that the aircraft is (see LAPL/PPL 010-03):
On the controlled airport you noticed a square yellow board bearing a black "C",exposed above one of the doors (Picture C). What does that mean? (seeLAPL/PPL 010-04)
In the signal area of an aerodrome, a red square with a single yellow diagonalstrip (Picture B) means: (see LAPL/PPL 010-04)

answers.answerText: Take special care when landing because of the poor state of the manoeuvring area.

question: What is the meaning of the visual ground signal in a form of a horizontal redsquare panel with yellow diagonals displayed in an airport signal area (PictureA)? (see LAPL/PPL 010-04)

answers.answerText: Area unfit for movement of aircraft.
Special precautions must be observed in approaching to land or in landing.
Aircraft are required to land, takeoff and taxi on runways and taxiways only.

question: A white cross, placed horizontally on the beginning of the taxiway (picture G),means: (see LAPL/PPL 010-04)

answers.answerText: Caution, you are approaching the intersection with the runway!
Caution, you are approaching the intersection with other taxiway!

question: In the signal area of an aerodrome, a double white cross (Picture H) means: (seeLAPL/PPL 010-04)

answers.answerText: Landing prohibited, the airport is not safe!
Ground taxiing permitted outside runway and taxiways!
Take special care during approach and landing!

question: In the signal area of an aerodrome, a white dumb-bell (Picture D) means: (seeLAPL/PPL 010-04)

answers.answerText: Landing direction is parallel with the shafts towards the cross-arm.
Aircraft are required to land, take off and taxi on runways and taxiways only.

question: In the signal area of an aerodrome, a white dumb-bell with black stripes on eachcircular portion at right angles to the shaft (Picture E) means: (see LAPL/PPL010-04)

answers.answerText: Landing, takeoff, and taxiing confined to runway and taxiways only.
Aircraft are required to land and take off on runways only, but other manoeuvres need notbe confined to runways and taxiways.

question: What marking may be displayed by day on an aerodrome to indicateunserviceability of any portion of a manoeuvring area?

answers.answerText: Crosses of single conspicuous color (preferably white) displayed horizontally.
Orange flags bordering the unserviceable area.
White and orange cones bordering the unserviceable area.
Large red squares with yellow diagonal markings displayed horizontally.

question: In the signal area of an aerodrome, a sign (Picture I), means: (see LAPL/PPL 010-04)

answers.answerText: Turns are to be made to the right before landing and after take-off.
Continue to the next airport, the runway is closed.
After landing vacate the runway by right turn.

question: In the signal area of an aerodrome, a white "T" (Picture F) means: (see LAPL/PPL010-04)

answers.answerText: Landing and take-off direction is parallel with the shafts towards the cross-arm.
Land and taxi on hard surfaces only.

question: At least how many hours of dual instruction on an aircraft must an applicanthave for a LAPL(A)?
At least how many hours of dual instruction on an aircraft must an applicanthave for a LAPL(H)?
At least how long must the cross-country flight, required for the eligibility for thePPL(H) skill test, be and how many full stop landing at different aerodromesmust be made at this flight?
At least how many hours of flying experience as a pilot of the aircraft must anapplicant have for a LAPL(A)?
At least how many hours of flying experience as a pilot of the aircraft must anapplicant have for a LAPL(H)?
Estimated time of arrival in VFR flight means time, when:

answers.answerText: The aircraft is estimated to stop taxiing at the destination aerodrome
The aircraft is estimated to vacate the runway of the destination aerodrome
The aircraft is estimated to land to the destination aerodrome
The aircraft is estimated to arrive over the destination aerodrome

question: Estimated off-block time means time, when the aircraft:

answers.answerText: Will commence taxiing associated with departure

question: How many Annexes ICAO Convention contains?
Movement area consists:

answers.answerText: Standard departure and arrival routes and runway

question: SEP (single engine piston) class rating is valid:
Runway end lights are:
You notice right after departure that your radio is broken. Tower shows series ofwhite flashes to you. What does this mean?

answers.answerText: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling.
Land at this aerodrome and proceed to apron.

question: The air traffic control can use light signals when radio communications are notpossible. For an aircraft on ground, a red flashing light means:

answers.answerText: Taxi clear from landing area in use
Vacate manouvering area in accordance with local instructions
Permission to cross landing area or to move onto taxiway

question: Series of red flashes to an aircraft in flight mean:

answers.answerText: Notwithstanding any previous instructions, do not land for the time being

question: In Finland transition altitude is:
Manouvering area includes:

answers.answerText: All parts of the movement area including the routes on the area

question: Aircraft can be registered to Finland if:

answers.answerText: The aircraft has type approval from FAA
The aircraft has certificate of airworthiness that is given in Finland
The aircraft is registered to other country

question: You notice a military aircraft on your left side. The aircraft is rocking and afterthat it makes a slow level turn to the left. You respond by:

answers.answerText: Flashing navigational lights and selecting frequency 119,7 MHz.
Rocking aircraft and continue flight normally.

question: Series of green flashes to an aircraft on the ground mean:

answers.answerText: Return to starting point on the aerodrome.

question: Red pyrotechnic for an aircraft in flight means:

answers.answerText: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling.
Orbit right until you get landing clearance.
Notwithstanding any previous instructions, do not land for the time being
Caution, military exercises in the area.

question: Minimum altitude (excluding landing and departure) over congested areas is:

answers.answerText: 1000 ft above the highest obstacle within radius of 600 meters
500 ft above the highest obstacle within radius of 600 meters

question: Abbreviation for terminal control area is:
Mandatory instructions, for example holding position signs are:
According to the rules of air, series of white flashes to an aircraft on the groundmean:

answers.answerText: Taxi clear of landing are in use.
Land at this aerodrome and proceed to apron. Clearance to land is given separately.
Return to starting point on the aerodrome.
Cleared for taxiing. Clearance for take-off is given separetely.

question: In which regulation series regulations concerning personnel licensing are?
Series of green flashes to aircraft in flight mean:

answers.answerText: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling

question: Abbreviation for control zone is:
If you have not received other instructions, after departure you:

answers.answerText: Do not make turns until you are outside of the traffic circuit

question: Controlled flight is:

answers.answerText: A flight that operates under ATC clearance
A flight that is operated according to IFR
A flight with a flight plan

question: Abbreviation VMC means:
Flight visibility defined as:

answers.answerText: Maximum distance from which an aircraft can be observed
The forward horizontal visibility from the cockpit during a flight
Defined visibility in aerodrome made by legal observer
Maximum distance from which big enough dark object can be observed and identifiedwhen observation is made against enlightned background

question: In ICAO emergency phases, alert phase means:

answers.answerText: A situation wherein it is certain that an aircraft does not require instant assistance
A situation wherein the state of the aircraft is unknown
A situation wherein aircraft has not arrived to destination aerodrome within 30 minutesafter estimated arrival time, and when there is no radio contact to the the aircraft
A situation wherein aircraft's performance has declined so that emergency landing isprobable

question: Uncertainty phase means:

answers.answerText: None of the alternatives is correct.
A situation wherein exists certainty about the safety of an aircraft and ts occupants, orthere exists other reasons to take actions in order to make sure if there is a need for help.
A situation wherein exists uncertainty about the safety of an aircraft and ts occupants, orthere exists other reasons to take actions in order to make sure if there is a need for help.
A situation wherein an aircraft has not send requested location.

question: "V" search and rescue ground signal in the scene of accident symbolizes:
If an aircraft does not give landing report agreed in the flight plan within 30minutes from landing, the situation is called:
"X" search and rescue ground signal symbolizes:
Arrow search and rescue ground signal symbolizes:

answers.answerText: Arrow is not a search and rescue ground signal
